title: What are differences between “they are taken care of..” and “they are being taken care of..” Both are present tense and is it superfluous to have (being)? - Quora

response.answer_text: They are both present tense, but the one with being has progressive aspect. This locates the focus of the action internal to the time-period the verb refers to: ”They are being taken care of” - the process is ongoing at the time of utterance, “at present”. “They are taken care of” - the present tense in its own, in a main clause, usually refers to a generic activity that applies at all times, e.g. “Kangaroos are taken care of by their mothers until they are able to forage for themselves”. The present also often refers to future time: “There’s no point building facilities for them - from next July they are taken care of by the State.” Basically there are strong constraints against the use of the present tense on its own to refer to present time (its better name is the non-past tense). If you want to refer to what is happening now, at least in a main clause, you normally need progressive aspect.

‘Taken care of' is present perfect tense. It implies a task is already done but at an unspecified time. We are also more concerned about the present impact of the task than the task itself. “Need help with your math problems?” “No, they are taken care of.” 'Being taken care of' is present continuous tense. It implies that the task is still ongoing. “Are the children ok?” “Yes, they are being taken care of”
